setup.question: The crew agrees that the city is
answers: full of magical wonders and they must return to the mother ship to let the others know.

Text.text: A crew of
encounter a city on an alien planet. They are supposed to investigate this city that's from the beginning described as having many various wonders about it:

.

Here are some other quotes that describe the city as full of magical wonders:
They want to take photos to show everyone else, but the camera is left behind so they must go back themselves to tell everyone about the city.

It is interesting that you are defining magical in terms of lifeless. I would describe magical as life affirming and wonderous and life giving. Can you explain why your magical quotes seem to describe lack of life and defend how this suppourts a magical place?

Also, please show text that proves they wanted to let the others know

Sure, the story is a sci-fi story and as such, the instances of magical wonder all have something to do with scientific advancements which end up having a lifeless tone to them.

They want to let others know which is proven by the whole deal with the pictures as well as the fact that they signal to
in order to get back and inform the others of what they've seen.

Interesting, can you show more evidence on them discussing why they must return to the mother ship or evidence showing them saying how they need to communicate this revelation with the others.

Also, please describe the role of machines in this world and how they factor into world building
In the beginning of the story it's mentioned that the goal of the crew is to scout out the new planet (36-37). The story also mentions  that
, it also says that the goal of the expeditions was
. The issue is though that all the previous scouts

which is where the story picks up.

The machines factor into world building because in order to get out of the city the crew has to get through the water treatment facility; see this discussion between two of the crew members:

Got it, so according to this the plot points are, they go see the city, determine it's magical, try to return to the ship, but face difficulties doing so? is that correct? and if so, can you provide more evidence of difficulties and challenges in terms of leaving the city and further plot points as to what happens in the rest of the story and how it ends?

Yes, the story's plot is, roughly, the explorers go to the city, need to get back to the mother ship but realize they're trapped, and escape through the water pipes.

The thing that traps them is a mysterious glass wall:
The band is mentioned to be everywhere:

.

They think for a while and conclude that it's an anti-radiation screen that triggered when their ship landed:
They try to phone the ship to get back but the screen blocks radio communication:

Right, this is very helpful. Thank you. However, I'm wondering if maybe they go back to the ship because they realize that the city is a machine and the machine is trying to kill them. Like, this may be to semantic, but perhaps they return not to tell the crew of the magical wonders but because they are fleeing the city/machine and trying to survive. Can you show ev that displays that their motivation for returning to the ship is to share the wonders of the city and not b/c they are fleeing? Thx
Sure, their original mission in fact was to explore this city (see the second to last speech). They need to "escape" the city because

, and they need to get back before then. The city isn't trapping them because it's a "machine" but rather because of the radiation screen which triggered when they landed there. The urgency isn't because the machine might kill them but because they have a time constraint on their mission and need to get back before then.
Ok I think that makes sense...how does the story end plot wise?
The story ends when they escape from the city and see the scoutships from the mothership:
Ok I don't love it but i'm going with it.

answers.reason for outcome: I could hide key pieces of information and quotes.
I thought that the quotes supported the story that the debater was presenting, and I need to do a better job being skeptical and probing deeper, and asking for more context on quotes.
